oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside advertising a demonstration of "Edison's Talking Machine or Phonograph" at a cost of 25 cents for adults and 15 cents for children. It claims that the machine will repeat distinctly every word spoken for years after, and that "it is not a telephone but an instrument that speaks for itself." It features testimonials from previous witnesses of the machine.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thomas Edison invented the cylinder phonograph in 1877. Edison began selling them commercially starting in the 1890s and continued to sell cylindrical phonographs until the technology was superseded by disc recordings in 1913.
